Constitution: previous 1978 (at independence); latest effective 1 October 1986; amended 2007, 2010 (2010)
Geography - note: one of the smallest and most remote countries on Earth; six of the nine coral atolls - Nanumea, Nui, Vaitupu, Nukufetau, Funafuti, and Nukulaelae - have lagoons open to the ocean; Nanumaya and Niutao have landlocked lagoons; Niulakita does not have a lagoon
Flag description: light blue with the flag of the UK in the upper hoist-side quadrant; the outer half of the flag represents a map of the country with nine yellow, five-pointed stars on a blue field symbolizing the nine atolls in the ocean
Government type: parliamentary democracy and a Commonwealth realm
Political parties and leaders: there are no political parties but members of parliament usually align themselves in informal groupings
Environment - current issues: since there are no streams or rivers and groundwater is not potable, most water needs must be met by catchment systems with storage facilities (the Japanese Government has built one desalination plant and plans to build one other); beachhead erosion because of the use of sand for building materials; excessive clearance of forest undergrowth for use as fuel; damage to coral reefs from the spread of the Crown of Thorns starfish; Tuvalu is concerned about global increases in greenhouse gas emissions and their effect on rising sea levels, which threaten the country's underground water table; in 2000, the government appealed to Australia and New Zealand to take in Tuvaluans if rising sea levels should make evacuation necessary
International law organization participa: has not submitted an ICJ jurisdiction declaration; non-party state to the ICCt
Imports - commodities: food, animals, mineral fuels, machinery, manufactured goods
Location: Oceania, island group consisting of nine coral atolls in the South Pacific Ocean, about one-half of the way from Hawaii to Australia
Natural hazards: severe tropical storms are usually rare, but in 1997 there were three cyclones; low levels of islands make them sensitive to changes in sea level
Area - comparative: 0.1 times the size of Washington, DC
Labor force - by occupation: people make a living mainly through exploitation of the sea, reefs, and atolls and through overseas remittances (mostly from workers in the phosphate industry and sailors)
Diplomatic representation from the US: the US does not have an embassy in Tuvalu; the US ambassador to Fiji, currently Ambassador Frankie A. REED, is accredited to Tuvalu
Religions: Protestant 98.4% (Church of Tuvalu (Congregationalist) 97%, Seventh-Day Adventist 1.4%), Baha'i 1%, other 0.6%
International organization participation: ACP, ADB, AOSIS, C, FAO, IBRD, IDA, IFRCS (observer), ILO, IMF, IMO, IOC, ITU, OPCW, PIF, Sparteca, SPC, UN, UNCTAD, UNESCO, UNIDO, UPU, WHO
Languages: Tuvaluan (official), English (official), Samoan, Kiribati (on the island of Nui)
Country name: "Tuvalu" means "group of eight" referring to the country's eight traditionally inhabited islands
Mother's mean age at first birth: median age at first birth among women 25-29 (2007 est.)
Diplomatic representation in the US: Note - Tuvalu does not have an embassy in Washington, D.C.; UN office located at 800 2nd Avenue, Suite 400D, New York, NY 10017
Administrative divisions: 7 island councils and 1 town council*; Funafuti*, Nanumaga, Nanumea, Niutao, Nui, Nukufetau, Nukulaelae, Vaitupu
Climate: tropical; moderated by easterly trade winds (March to November); westerly gales and heavy rain (November to March)
Telephone system: serves particular needs for internal communications
country code - 688; international calls can be made by satellite (2007)
Legal system: mixed legal system of English common law and local customary law
Capital: Funafuti; note - administrative offices are in Vaiaku Village on Fongafale Islet
UTC+12 (17 hours ahead of Washington, DC, during Standard Time)
Exchange rates: Tuvaluan dollars or Australian dollars (AUD) per US dollar -
Broadcast media: no TV stations; many households use satellite dishes to watch foreign TV stations; 1 government-owned radio station, Radio Tuvalu, includes relays of programming from international broadcasters (2009)
National anthem: "Tuvalu mo te Atua" (Tuvalu for the Almighty)
adopted 1978; the anthem's name is also the nation's motto
